CONCLUSION: Preliminary objection partially rejected (non-exhaustion of domestic remedies);Preliminary objection partially joined to merits (victim);Preliminary objection partially allowed (victim);No violation of Art. 5-3;No violation of Art. 5-4
JUDGES: Giovanni Bonello;Lech Garlicki;Ledi Bianku;Nebojša Vučinić;Nicolas Bratza;Päivi Hirvelä
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and is currently serving a prison sentence in GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE , pursuant to an arrest warrant issued by the NORP authorities on DATE , the applicant was arrested and detained in GPE on suspicion of having conspired in the traffic of cocaine , ecstasy and cannabis .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant , through his legal counsel , challenged the lawfulness of his arrest and detention in so far as the arrest warrant had not been issued in accordance with the NORP Arrest Warrant requirements ( in force on DATE ) .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE , ORG of GPE rejected the applicant ’s claim as the extradition request had been made prior to the new arrest warrant procedure with the result that the previous law applied .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was extradited to GPE to stand trial on charges of drug trafficking .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was brought before ORG as a ORG . He challenged the legality of the arrest warrant of DATE . He claimed that the prosecution had to satisfy ORG that the arrest had been lawful and that this could not be assumed , given in particular that the accused had not been personally heard . The applicant argued that the procedure followed by the prosecution , whereby it simply confirmed on oath the report containing the legal provisions on which the charges were based , did not satisfy the requirements of LAW . He made reference in this connection to ORG judgment in GPE v. GPE , ( no . MONEY , DATE ) .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant pleaded not guilty . He also pointed out that he was contesting the NORP courts’ jurisdiction to try him , claiming that the facts he was accused of did not constitute an offence under the laws of GPE .

CARDINAL . The prosecution submitted that the applicant had been brought to GPE following the issue of an arrest warrant by the duty magistrate . Upon the applicant ’s arrival and within TIME of the arrest , the duty magistrate was informed of the arrest and confirmed its continuation . Within TIME of the arrest , during which time he was interrogated , the applicant was arraigned before the court . The prosecution further submitted that the case which carried a maximum punishment of life imprisonment was based on the testimony of various civilian witnesses and corroborating evidence .
CARDINAL . At the hearing ORG took account of the applicant ’s not - guilty plea . The hearing TIME read as follows :

“ In regard to whether the accused is going to plead guilty or not guilty as charged the same accused would like to point out that first of all he is contesting the jurisdiction of the NORP courts to try him and secondly that the facts do not constitute , in his regard , an offence under the laws of GPE and thirdly that he is not guilty of any fact alleged against him . To all intents and purposes of law , the ORG [ of Magistrates ] , having heard what has just been put down in the records of the proceedings , is considering the accused as pleading not guilty as charged . ”

ORG did not require the arresting officer to justify why the applicant had been arrested or why his detention was necessary . It declared , without entering TIME to that effect in the records , that the warrant had been issued by a magistrate and confirmed by another magistrate and both sets of proceedings had been held in camera and the arrest had been authorised . Moreover , the case had been examined by the NORP courts in the context of their consideration of GPE ’s request for the applicant ’s extradition . In TIME it further referred to the fact that the validity of the warrant as regards its procedural aspects was affirmed by ORG in a further set of proceedings which took place while the applicant was still in GPE . Thus , the warrant was sufficient to enable the arrest to be considered lawful at that stage of the proceedings . Nothing had been brought to the attention of the court which enabled it to say that the person charged was under arrest without justification .

CARDINAL . NORP Since the applicant insisted that his arrest was unlawful and unjustified no request for bail was made and he was remanded in custody . His case file was transmitted to another magistrate sitting in ORG in order to proceed with the committal stage .
CARDINAL . In the meantime , on DATE , the applicant applied for bail .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG in the committal stage heard the parties . The applicant advanced once again his argument that the NORP authorities lacked jurisdiction to try him .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG rejected the application for bail , which had been lodged on DATE , on the grounds that there was a real danger that the applicant might abscond , leave the island or interfere or attempt to interfere with witnesses . It further held that it was not competent to give a ruling on the question of jurisdiction and decided that there were enough grounds to commit the applicant for trial .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant applied to ORG ( FAC ) in its constitutional jurisdiction , alleging that both at his first hearing and at the committal stage , LAW and CARDINAL of the LAW had been violated . ORG had failed to assess the lawfulness of the arrest by refusing to decide on the defence ’s objections , namely that the NORP courts did not have jurisdiction to try the defendant and that the facts alleged against him did not constitute a criminal offence under NORP law . The applicant therefore requested ORG to declare that his arrest and continued detention were unlawful and to order his release and provide him with adequate redress .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE , ORG rejected the applicant ’s claim . It held that ORG as a ORG was bound to examine solely the lawfulness of the arrest and , if necessary , to order release on bail according to Article CARDINAL of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . The question of jurisdiction related to the merits of the case and therefore could be examined only by ORG . This was not in violation of the Convention .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant appealed to ORG . He reiterated his claims and emphasised that LAW was not an effective remedy as it provided only for provisional release under guarantee or against payment of bail and not unconditional release as required by LAW .
CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court heard submissions on CARDINAL and DATE .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE , ORG upheld the applicant ’s appeal in part . It first held that at the hearing of DATE ORG had satisfied its duty under LAW and CARDINAL of the LAW as provided by LAW ( see paragraph DATE , in fine , below ) . In particular , it had heard the parties’ submissions regarding the lawfulness of record ) and because it would have substantially amounted to a plea that the facts of the case did not constitute a crime . Thus , further evidence would have been necessary in order to decide the matter .

CARDINAL . ORG did , however , find a violation of LAW in so far as on DATE ORG at the committal stage ( LAW had abstained from deciding the issue of jurisdiction , thus disregarding its duty to determine the lawfulness of the applicant ’s detention under LAW . Even though questions of jurisdiction would , in principle , be dealt with by ORG , in the applicant ’s case this issue was interconnected with the factual requirements of the criminal offence . In the absence of solid factual grounds against the defendant , ORG could not commit him for trial . ORG annulled the ORG of GPE order of CARDINAL DATE committing the applicant for trial as well as all subsequent acts . It remitted the case to ORG to be decided afresh after taking cognisance of the applicant ’s plea of lack of jurisdiction . It awarded the applicant CARDINAL NORP Liras ( MTL – approximately MONEY ( ORG ) ) for just satisfaction , and ordered the payment of the costs of the proceedings to be divided between the parties .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant applied for bail before ORG , the competent court at the time . On DATE the Attorney General sent the records of the proceedings back to ORG . Thus , on DATE ORG refused to take cognisance of the request as it no longer had jurisdiction in the matter .
CARDINAL . On DATE the same application was filed with ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG refused to release the applicant , having regard to the nature and seriousness of the offence , the real danger of the accused absconding or leaving the island and obstructing or attempting to obstruct the course of justice .
CARDINAL . On DATE the President of GPE issued a warrant extending the legal time - limit for concluding the proceedings to DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant , still under arrest , was brought before ORG . He alleged that the law imposed a peremptory time - limit of DATE for the conclusion of the committal proceedings . In the applicant ’s view , this time - limit could not be extended by ORG , as had occurred in his case . Furthermore , the applicant challenged the magistrate sitting in his case on the ground that she had already sat in the hearings preceding the constitutional proceedings . He invoked the principles laid down by ORG in PERSON and PERSON v. GPE ( see judgment of DATE , Reports of Judgments and Decisions PERSON ) . He also raised once again his plea based on the NORP authorities’ lack of jurisdiction to try him .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG considered that the CARDINAL day time - limit had not been exceeded since ORG had placed the applicant in a status quo ante . Moreover , the warrant of the President of GPE extending the term of the inquiry had been valid according to law . It rejected the challenge to the magistrate on the ground that that court had refrained from giving a definitive judgment on the merits of the case , thus satisfying the objective impartiality test . ORG further stated that the interpretation of LAW f ) of the LAW extended the principle of territorial jurisdiction and that it therefore had jurisdiction to proceed against the applicant . It decided to commit the applicant for trial .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant filed an application with ORG , the competent court at the material time , to challenge the lawfulness of his detention according to LAW . He requested it to order his release from custody . He also complained that the committing magistrate , who delivered the decision of CARDINAL DATE , had erred when she refrained from stepping down once she had been challenged .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the application as being unfounded for the purposes of LAW It held that even if the magistrate had erred , this did not render the detention unlawful . Moreover , the proceedings leading to the decision of DATE appeared to have been properly initiated and conducted , as indicated by ORG judgment of DATE , which upheld only the applicant ’s complaint about the irregularity related to the refusal to consider the plea of jurisdiction .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant filed a new application with ORG , claiming that the Attorney General had exceeded the time - limit allowed for filing the bill of indictment . On an unspecified date ORG rejected the claim .
CARDINAL . On an unspecified date the Attorney General filed the bill of indictment . As a consequence , ORG became competent to take cognisance of any application for release .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant applied for bail , making reference to GPE v. GPE ( [ ORG ] , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , ORG CARDINAL-IV ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was granted bail against payment of a deposit of ORG CARDINAL ( approximately EUR CARDINAL,CARDINAL ) . He was put under house arrest at his mother ’s home . He was only allowed to go out for TIME in the morning to report to the police station .
CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG had started examining the plea of lack of jurisdiction . The applicant was still under house arrest .

CARDINAL . On an unspecified date the applicant made another request for his detention arrangements to be alleviated . On DATE ORG rejected his request , emphasising that it could not be said that the applicant was under arrest but was simply confined and limited in TIME during which he could leave his house as a condition of his being granted provisional liberty .
CARDINAL . By a judgment of ORG of DATE , confirmed by ORG on DATE , the applicant was found guilty of the charges against him and sentenced to a term of imprisonment .
CARDINAL . According to recent amendments to LAW adopted in DATE , a police inspector may no longer arrest a suspect under his own authority but has to apply to a GPE chamber for an arrest warrant .
Article CARDINAL

“ Where there are lawful grounds for the arrest of a person , the police may request a warrant of arrest from a magistrate , unless in accordance with any provision of law the arrest in question may be made without a warrant . ”
CARDINAL . Following amendments adopted in DATE and DATE , the Articles of LAW , in so far as relevant , read as follows :
Article CARDINAL ( CARDINAL )
“ ( CARDINAL ) On the conclusion of the inquiry , the court shall decide whether there are or not sufficient grounds for committing the accused for trial on indictment . ”
Article CARDINALA

“ ( CARDINAL ) Any person who alleges he is being unlawfully detained under the authority of the police or of any other public authority not in connection with any offence with which he is charged or accused before a court may at any time apply to ORG , which shall have the same powers which that court has as a court of criminal inquiry , demanding his release from custody . Any such application shall be appointed for hearing with urgency and the application together with the date of the hearing shall be served on DATE of the application on the applicant and on the Commissioner of Police or on the public authority under whose authority the applicant is allegedly being unlawfully detained . The Commissioner of Police or public authority , as the case may be , may file a reply by not later than the day of the hearing .

( CARDINAL ) On DATE appointed for the hearing of the application the court shall summarily hear the applicant and the respondents and any relevant evidence produced by them in support of their submissions and on the reasons and circumstances militating in favour of or against the lawfulness of the continued detention of the applicant .

( CARDINAL ) If , having heard the evidence produced and the submissions made by the applicant and respondents , the court finds that the continued detention of the applicant is not founded on any provision of this LAW or of any other law which authorises the arrest and detention of the applicant it shall allow the application . Otherwise the court shall refuse the application .

( CARDINAL ) Where the court decides to allow the application the record of the proceedings including a copy of the court ’s decision shall be transmitted to the Attorney General by not later than the next working day and the Attorney General may , within DATE from the receipt of the record and if he is of the opinion that the arrest and continued detention of the person released from custody was founded on any provision of this LAW or of any other law , apply to ORG to obtain the re - arrest and continued detention of the person so released from custody . The record of the proceedings and the court ’s decision transmitted to the Attorney General under the provisions of this sub - article shall be filed together with the application by the Attorney General to ORG . ”
Article CARDINAL

“ ( CARDINAL ) Any person in custody for an offence of which he is charged or accused before ORG and who , at any stage other than that to which Article CARDINAL applies , alleges that his continued detention is not in accordance with the law may at any time apply to the court demanding his release from custody . Any such application shall be appointed for hearing with urgency and together with the date of the hearing shall be served on DATE of the application on the Commissioner of Police or , as the case may be , on the Commissioner of Police and the Attorney General , who may file a reply thereto by not later than the day of the hearing .
( CARDINAL ) The provisions of LAW and ( CARDINAL ) shall apply mutatis mutandis to an application under this article .

( CARDINAL ) Where the application is filed in connection with proceedings pending before ORG as a court of criminal inquiry before a bill of indictment has been filed and the record of the inquiry is with the Attorney General in connection with any act of the proceedings , the application shall be filed in ORG and the aforegoing provisions of this Article shall apply mutatis mutandis thereto . ”
( CARDINAL ) The provisions of LAW ) shall apply to a decision of ORG under this Article . ”
Article CARDINALA

“ ( CARDINAL ) When the person charged or accused who is in custody is first brought before ORG , whether as a court of criminal judicature or as a court of criminal inquiry , the ORG shall have the charges read out to the person charged or accused and , after examining the person charged as provided in LAW as the proceedings may require , shall summarily hear the prosecuting or arraigning officer and any evidence produced by that officer on the reasons supporting the charges and on the reasons and circumstances , if any , militating against the release of the person charged or accused .

( CARDINAL ) After hearing the prosecuting or arraigning police officer and any evidence produced as provided in sub - article ( CARDINAL ) the court shall inform the person charged or accused that he may be temporarily released from custody on bail by the court under conditions to be determined by it and shall ask him what he has to say with respect to his arrest and his continued detention and with respect to the reasons and the circumstances militating in favour of his release .

( CARDINAL ) Where any of the offences charged consists in any of the offences mentioned in LAW ) the court shall , after hearing the person charged or accused as provided in sub - article ( CARDINAL ) of this article , ask the prosecuting or arraigning officer whether he has any submissions to make on the question of temporary release from custody on bail of the person charged or accused and the latter shall be allowed to respond .
( CARDINAL ) At the end of submissions as provided in the preceding sub - articles of this Article the court shall review the circumstances militating for or against detention .

( CARDINAL ) If the court finds that the continued detention of the person charged or accused is not founded on any provision of this LAW or of any other law which authorises the arrest and detention of the person in custody it shall unconditionally release that person from custody .

( CARDINAL ) If the court does not find cause to release unconditionally the person charged or accused ... it may nevertheless ... release that person from custody on bail subject to such conditions as it may deem appropriate .
( CARDINAL) If the court does not find cause to release unconditionally the person charged or accused and refuses to grant that person bail the court shall remand that person into custody ... ”
CARDINAL . LAW , in so far as relevant , reads as follows :
Article CARDINAL
“ ( CARDINAL ) The Constitutional Court shall ... have jurisdiction to hear and determine all appeals under LAW and exercise all such powers as are conferred on it by this LAW . ”
Article CARDINAL

“ ( CARDINAL ) Any person who alleges that any of FAC , has been , is being or is likely to be contravened in relation to him , or such other person as ORG , ORG , in GPE may appoint at the instance of any person who so alleges , may , without prejudice to any other action with respect to the same matter that is lawfully available , apply to ORG , ORG , for redress .

( CARDINAL ) ORG , ORG , shall have original jurisdiction to hear and determine any application made by any person in pursuance of sub - article ( CARDINAL ) , and may make such orders , issue such writs and give such directions as it may consider appropriate for the purpose of enforcing , or securing the enforcement , of FAC to the enjoyment of which the person concerned is entitled :

Provided that the court may , if it considers it desirable so to do , decline to exercise its powers under this sub - article in any case where it is satisfied that adequate means of redress for the contravention alleged are or have been available to the person concerned under any other ordinary law .
( CARDINAL ) Any party to proceedings brought in ORG , ORG , in pursuance of this article shall have a right of appeal to ORG . ”

Consequently , a complaint must be lodged with both instances before it is introduced with ORG . However , in PERSON v. GPE , ( no . CARDINAL , DATE , § CARDINAL ) and ORG v. GPE , ( cited above , § CARDINAL ) , the ORG held that this procedure was rather cumbersome and therefore lodging a constitutional application would not have ensured a speedy review of the lawfulness of the applicant ’s detention . Consequently in the cited cases the applicants had not had at their disposal , under domestic law , a remedy for challenging the lawfulness of their detention under LAW .
